rev.comment: This image use does not comply with [[WP:NFCC]] #10c and MUST be removed until it does. Thank you. See [[WP:FIXNF]] and [[WP:10CR]]
rev.diff:
Line 45: Line 45:
The first track on the album, "[[Power (KMFDM song)|Power]]", was featured on the "Wax Trax! Summer Swindle", a cassette sampler included with 45,000 issues of the July 1996 issue of ''Alternative Press''.<ref name="Billboard Newspaper"/> Another 50,000 copies of the sampler were to be handed out at summer college and beach events and given away at radio stations.<ref name="Billboard Newspaper"/> 90,000 pre-release posters and information sheets were mailed out to fans.<ref name="Billboard Newspaper"/>
The first track on the album, "[[Power (KMFDM song)|Power]]", was featured on the "Wax Trax! Summer Swindle", a cassette sampler included with 45,000 issues of the July 1996 issue of ''Alternative Press''.<ref name="Billboard Newspaper"/> Another 50,000 copies of the sampler were to be handed out at summer college and beach events and given away at radio stations.<ref name="Billboard Newspaper"/> 90,000 pre-release posters and information sheets were mailed out to fans.<ref name="Billboard Newspaper"/>
â
[[File:Son of a Gun.jpg|thumb|left|220px|The character Son of a Gun from the video of the same name.]][[Nicole Blackman]] wrote the promotional piece for the album's press kit,<ref name="Transmission">{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/news/arch-frame.htm | title=March 16 2007: Transmission 4.206 | date=March 16, 2007 | accessdate=March 15, 2010}}</ref> and at the request of [[Sascha Konietzko]],<ref name="Transmission"/> wrote the first half of the promo as an insulting take down of the album rather than as a standard promo. The first letter of each line of the first section of the promo spelled out the phrase "April Fools Day Fucker"<ref name="Press Kit">{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/xtort.html | title=Xtort Press Folder | accessdate=March 15, 2010}}</ref> and included lines such as "It's been 100 years and fifty albums for the German/American rock squad â are they running out of gas or what?"<ref name="Press Kit"/> and "KMFDM can't suck hard enough!"<ref name="Press Kit"/> The second half of the promo included phrases such as "''XTORT'' is a supersonic soundtrack"<ref name="Press Kit"/> and "The new album is the sound of a band at the height of their powers."<ref name="Press Kit"/> Carrie Borzillo of ''Billboard Newspaper'' stated that KMFDM was "poised to make a significant commercial breakthrough."<ref name="Billboard Newspaper"/> Konietzko stated at the time that there were no plans to tour in support of the album's release.<ref name="Billboard Newspaper"/>
+
[[Nicole Blackman]] wrote the promotional piece for the album's press kit,<ref name="Transmission">{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/news/arch-frame.htm | title=March 16 2007: Transmission 4.206 | date=March 16, 2007 | accessdate=March 15, 2010}}</ref> and at the request of [[Sascha Konietzko]],<ref name="Transmission"/> wrote the first half of the promo as an insulting take down of the album rather than as a standard promo. The first letter of each line of the first section of the promo spelled out the phrase "April Fools Day Fucker"<ref name="Press Kit">{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/xtort.html | title=Xtort Press Folder | accessdate=March 15, 2010}}</ref> and included lines such as "It's been 100 years and fifty albums for the German/American rock squad â are they running out of gas or what?"<ref name="Press Kit"/> and "KMFDM can't suck hard enough!"<ref name="Press Kit"/> The second half of the promo included phrases such as "''XTORT'' is a supersonic soundtrack"<ref name="Press Kit"/> and "The new album is the sound of a band at the height of their powers."<ref name="Press Kit"/> Carrie Borzillo of ''Billboard Newspaper'' stated that KMFDM was "poised to make a significant commercial breakthrough."<ref name="Billboard Newspaper"/> Konietzko stated at the time that there were no plans to tour in support of the album's release.<ref name="Billboard Newspaper"/>
''Xtort'' was released on June 25, 1996<ref name="Billboard Newspaper"/> on [[Wax Trax! Records|Wax Trax!]]/[[TVT Records|TVT]] on cassette,<ref name="discog">{{cite web | url=http://www.discogs.com/KMFDM-Xtort/master/8959 | title=KFMDM Xtort Releases | accessdate=March 28, 2010}}</ref> CD, and vinyl.<ref name="official">{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/discography/albums/xtort.htm | title=Xtort Tracklist | work=KMFDM.net | publisher=KMFDM Enterprises | accessdate=March 15, 2010}}</ref> The album was also released in CD format in Europe<ref name="discog"/> and Japan.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://joshinweb.jp/dps/art/13371-1.html | title=Xtort | work=joshinweb.jp | language=Japanese | accessdate=March 26, 2010}}</ref> In addition to being the first KMFDM album to chart in the ''Billboard'' 200, staying there for three weeks and peaking at No. 92 the week of July 13, 1996,<ref name="Billboard">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/#/artist/kmfdm/chart-history/11031|title=KMFDM Album & Song chart history|work=Billboard.com|accessdate=February 28, 2010}}</ref> ''Xtort'' sold over 200,000 copies,<ref name="Blog Critics">{{cite web | url=http://blogcritics.org/music/article/kmfdm/page-3/ | title=KMFDM Profile | author=Olsen, Eric | publisher=blogcritics.org | date=October 5, 2003 | accessdate=March 1, 2010}}</ref> making it the best-selling album in the band's history.<ref>{{cite album-notes | title=[[Greatest Shit]] | artist=KMFDM | year=2010 | format=CD booklet | publisher=[[Metropolis Records]] | location=Philadelphia, Pennsylvania}}</ref> The song "Son of a Gun" was made into an animated video by visual artist [[Aidan Hughes|Aidan "Brute!" Hughes]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bruteprop.co.uk/ | title=Brute! Propaganda | accessdate=March 15, 2010}}</ref> who also did the album's cover artwork.<ref name="Xtort 1996"/> On March 6, 2007, [[Metropolis Records]] released a digitally remastered version of the album on CD and MP3.<ref name="official"/><ref name="Metropolis">{{cite web | url=http://www.metropolis-mailorder.com/product.php?prodnum=MET+476 | title=Xtort at Metropolis Records | accessdate=March 15, 2010}}</ref>
''Xtort'' was released on June 25, 1996<ref name="Billboard Newspaper"/> on [[Wax Trax! Records|Wax Trax!]]/[[TVT Records|TVT]] on cassette,<ref name="discog">{{cite web | url=http://www.discogs.com/KMFDM-Xtort/master/8959 | title=KFMDM Xtort Releases | accessdate=March 28, 2010}}</ref> CD, and vinyl.<ref name="official">{{cite web | url=http://www.kmfdm.net/discography/albums/xtort.htm | title=Xtort Tracklist | work=KMFDM.net | publisher=KMFDM Enterprises | accessdate=March 15, 2010}}</ref> The album was also released in CD format in Europe<ref name="discog"/> and Japan.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://joshinweb.jp/dps/art/13371-1.html | title=Xtort | work=joshinweb.jp | language=Japanese | accessdate=March 26, 2010}}</ref> In addition to being the first KMFDM album to chart in the ''Billboard'' 200, staying there for three weeks and peaking at No. 92 the week of July 13, 1996,<ref name="Billboard">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/#/artist/kmfdm/chart-history/11031|title=KMFDM Album & Song chart history|work=Billboard.com|accessdate=February 28, 2010}}</ref> ''Xtort'' sold over 200,000 copies,<ref name="Blog Critics">{{cite web | url=http://blogcritics.org/music/article/kmfdm/page-3/ | title=KMFDM Profile | author=Olsen, Eric | publisher=blogcritics.org | date=October 5, 2003 | accessdate=March 1, 2010}}</ref> making it the best-selling album in the band's history.<ref>{{cite album-notes | title=[[Greatest Shit]] | artist=KMFDM | year=2010 | format=CD booklet | publisher=[[Metropolis Records]] | location=Philadelphia, Pennsylvania}}</ref> The song "Son of a Gun" was made into an animated video by visual artist [[Aidan Hughes|Aidan "Brute!" Hughes]],<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.bruteprop.co.uk/ | title=Brute! Propaganda | accessdate=March 15, 2010}}</ref> who also did the album's cover artwork.<ref name="Xtort 1996"/> On March 6, 2007, [[Metropolis Records]] released a digitally remastered version of the album on CD and MP3.<ref name="official"/><ref name="Metropolis">{{cite web | url=http://www.metropolis-mailorder.com/product.php?prodnum=MET+476 | title=Xtort at Metropolis Records | accessdate=March 15, 2010}}</ref>
